attributes.alt: Book cover for Me and My Cars by Liesbet Slegers. The cover art shows a boy holding up a toy car and a toy ambulance.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about location terms, engage children with a game, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
What do we use vehicles for?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, pointing out location words, and using terms.
Understand that each successive number counted represent a quantity that is one larger.
Use position words such as “over,” “under,” “above,” “on,” “beside,” “next to,” “between,” “in front of,” “near,” and “far,” “top,” “bottom,” “up,” “down,” and “behind.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Guide children to count the number of vehicles in the parade and add one to the end.
Help children recognize counting the next number means that there is one more.
What vehicles do we know about? How do they help us?
What vehicles are in this book?
Pretend you are a driver. What vehicle will you drive?
How can we sort these vehicles?
Which vehicle do you want to drive? Why?
Draw a picture of you driving a vehicle. What vehicle is it?
Use your finger to trace the  letter B for bus.
Can you build a ramp? Roll balls down it.

attributes.alt: Book cover for Me and My Cars by Liesbet Slegers. The cover art shows a boy holding up a toy car and a toy ambulance.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to classify and organize vehicles and to discuss classification by qualities.
Describe and sort objects by similarities and differences.
Understand that each successive number counted represents a quantity that is one larger.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Challenge children to sort the vehicles into groups based on attributes.
Guide children find a different way to sort and classify the vehicles.
What vehicles do we know about? How do they help us?
What do the vehicles in this  book do?
Pretend you are in a camper. What will you do besides sleep?
Here are some packages from a delivery truck. Which one is the biggest? Which one is the smallest?
Imagine a train. What does it carry?
Many vehicles have wheels. What can you use as wheels? Glue them on this paper.
Trace the word ride with your finger. Count the number of letters in the word.
What vehicle could help you make a tower?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Me and My Cars by Liesbet Slegers. The cover art shows a boy holding up a toy car and a toy ambulance.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to learn about counting, engage children with a game, and introduce vocabulary
How do the vehicles in the book help us?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to practice counting.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Understand that each successive number counted represents a quantity that is one larger.
Describe and sort objects by similarities and differences.
Use position words such as “over,” “under,” “above,” “on,” “beside,” “next to,” “between,” “in front of,” “near,” and “far,” “top,” “bottom,” “up,” “down,” and “behind.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Guide children to use location words to describe the placement of vehicles.
Guide children to create and describe their own placements of vehicles and practice location words.
What vehicles do we know about? How do they help us?
Do the vehicles in this book help?
Pretend you’re on a farm. What kind of vehicle might you drive?
What vehicles float? Which of these sink?
Can you make a steering wheel that moves? Pretend to drive.
Trace the letters C A R.
Build a hospital or doctor’s office. What vehicles would you see here?

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas for The Wheels on the Bus. There are six pictures: a bus with the words "round and round"; an airplane with the words "swoosh, swoosh, swoosh"; a car with the words "beep, beep, beep"; a boat with the words "splash, splash, splash"; a train with the words "chug, chug, chug"; and a backhoe with the words "dig, dig, dig.

elements.text: Big Chart of Big Ideas: The Wheels on the Bus

attributes.alt: Book cover for Me and My Cars by Liesbet Slegers. The cover art shows a boy holding up a toy car and a toy ambulance.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about shapes, engage children with a game about movement, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Read closely to connect to understanding how shapes create pictures and how vehicles move.
Combine shapes to create a picture or design.
Describe and sort objects by similarities and differences.
Use position words such as “over,” “under,” “above,” “on,” “beside,” “next to,” “between,” “in front of,” “near,” and “far,” “top,” “bottom,” “up,” “down,” and “behind.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.
Guide children to select named shapes.
Help children arrange the shapes using location words.
Challenge children to design new images from shapes.
What vehicles do we know about? How do they help us?
How do the vehicles in this book help the characters?
Drive a fire engine to the fire and then put the fire out.
Roll a car down a ramp. How can you change the ramp to make the car go faster?
What is the difference between a car and a bus?
You can buy tacos at a taco truck. What do you want to sell? Make a truck to sell it.
What sound do you hear at the beginning of vehicle?
Build a vehicle that has wings.

attributes.alt: Book cover for Me and My Cars by Liesbet Slegers. The cover art shows a boy holding up a toy car and a toy ambulance.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to connect to physical science, engage children with a song, and introduce new vocabulary
Start Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,
What kind of work do vehicles do?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and a focus on math skills.
Understand that each successive number counted represent a quantity that is one larger.
Use position words such as “over,” “under,” “above,” “on,” “beside,” “next to,” “between,” “in front of,” “near,” and “far,” “top,” “bottom,” “up,” “down,” and “behind.
Combine shapes to create a picture or design.
Describe and sort objects by similarities and differences.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
Describe a category of vehicle and some vehicles in it.
Save children’s writing to display next week.
What vehicles do we know about? How do they help us?
What do you like about the vehicles in this book?
Pretend to drive a tow truck. Hook a car up and pull it away.
Create a new design using pattern blocks.
Tell a story about a time that a vehicle helped you?
Use letters to make the word  car.
Can you build a helping vehicle?

Demonstrate use of location words (such as “over,” “under,” “above,” “on,” “beside,” “next to,” “between,” “in front of,” “near,” “far,” etc.)
Count up to 10 items and demonstrate that the last count indicates how many items were counted.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Sort objects that are the same and different into groups and use language to describe how the groups are similar and different.

Use art as a form of creative self-expression and representation.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss position and motion of objects.
